page.title: 07OLD SADDLEWORTH ARCHITECTUE
page.content: Two thirds of the area is high peat bog & rocky areas, so only the valley sides & floor are used for buildings. Dispersed about the hillsides are sturdy, stone-built farmhouses, former homes of farmer/weavers, dating from 17th & 18th centuries, alongside large clothiers homesteads, often with long lines of stone mullioned windows. Some show signs of enlargement to house the extra looms as trade expanded. Weavers cottages were grouped in clusters, eg. Saddleworth Fold, Shaws & Holly Grove. Holly Grove House (1800) is a fine example of a merchants house & the Cross Keys Inn (1745) has stone mullioned windows & hand-hewn beams. Terraced housing on the valley floor was built from 1850 onwards, made of locally-quarried stone, for workers at the newly-built cotton & woollen mills eg. Dobcross Loom Works (1860).
